heading: innocent plea in pairgain hoax
subheading: a north carolina man appears in a los angeles federal courtroom to answer charges of securities fraud. his case goes to trial in july.
author: wired news report
text: a former pairgain technologies engineer pleaded innocent to federal charges of fabricating a news report in order to drive up the stock price of his employer. gary dale hoke, of raleigh, north carolina, was ordered to stand trial on 6 july on five counts of securities fraud. if convicted, he faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a us$1-million fine. bail was set at $50,000.hoke, 25, is accused of posting a fake report suggesting that pairgain, a telecommunications equipment manufacturer based in tustin, california, was about to be acquired by an israeli company. the story was formatted to look like it had been posted on the bloomberg news web site.the 7 april hoax caused a 31 percent surge in pairgain's stock price, which fell when the company denied that such a deal was in the works.prosecutors have said that pairgain officials were not aware of the hoax. hoke worked for the company at the time of the scam but was later fired.prosecutors contend that hoke posted a bogus email message about pairgain under the subject line "buyout news" on yahoo's financial news message board. the message was hyperlinked to the phony bloomberg site.a day trader, hoke had owned stock in pairgain as recently as january, according to a federal affidavit.
